Award.AbstractNarration:
In industry, the design of a product is a multidisciplinary effort since engineers and technologists need to integrate the various laws of physics, optics, chemistry and thermodynamics and use algorithmic technical computing to analyze the design. The most fundamental abilities needed by workers in engineering and technology fields are problem-solving, critical thinking, and the ability to digest, analyze and communicate information; however, much of the student learning in technical fields has been along rigid disciplinary lines and has been visually static. To address this issue, Housatonic Community College is using integrated multidisciplinary software to develop software modules that teach mathematics, science, and engineering and engineering technology courses with the aid of 3D solid modeling software and embedding these modules into science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) courses. These modules are increasing fundamental abilities in understanding and applying engineering design principles for current students, new students, and incumbent workers. Links are being created by connecting three-dimensional solid modeling software to three-dimensional equations; using technical computing language software to connect equations with solid modeling software; and connecting physics based analysis to the design process. Students are thus experiencing direct application of engineering principles through visualization and thereby enhancing their understanding and appreciation of these principles.

All modular curricula being developed in this project are being tested, assessed, and disseminated to the twelve Connecticut Community Colleges and the four state universities. Partnering with the NSF Regional Center for Next Generation Manufacturing (RCNGM) has the potential to impact 4,500 community college students in the state of Connecticut, and this method of instruction and learning is being spread to high school level students and educators through local affiliates of Project Lead the Way. The NSF SC ATE Center of Excellence has agreed to distribute the modules.

The modular curricula being created use solid modeling and technical computing and focus on a particular task or application and link mathematics and engineering technology. Three dimensional objects and surfaces come alive visually in three dimensions with proper lighting, dynamic rotation, and interactive cross section visualization and with 3D printers. Students actually hold 3D mathematical equations in their hands. The modules are being used in classrooms that contain computers, the required software, and 3D printers and are being tested at the college with approximately 400 students who are taking Manufacturing Mathematics, Blueprint Reading, Computer Numerical Control classes, College Algebra, Precalculus, Statistics, Computer Aided Design, Statistical Process Control, Calculus, General Physics, General Chemistry, and pre-engineering courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Housatonic Community College (HCC) was granted a National Science Foundation award titled Linking Equations to Engineering Technology during the period from July 2014 to July 2018. The Linking Equations to Engineering Technology consisted of three primary goals, which produced the following outcomes.

The first goal of this grant is to demonstrate the innovative use of integrated multidisciplinary software to educate current and new students, as well as incumbent workers, in the STEM disciplines. This goal will make these students more proficient in fundamental abilities required for successful careers in engineering and manufacturing. This grant concentrated on two software packages that are heavily used in industry. In the engineering and manufacturing fields, it is common to see the analytical analysis software called Matlab being used both in industry and academia. Rapid prototyping is important to the design process. In engineering design, rapid prototyping consists of designing a part, transforming that part into an electronic solid model using computer aided design software, analyzing that model in thermal, structural, aerodynamic ... software, 3D-printing the part, and finally testing the part. The solid modeling software of choice for this grant was Solidworks. This grant also concentrated on the use of 3D-printing. Not only is it part of the rapid prototyping process, it is an excellent pedagogical tool. Two outcomes of this goal were the creation of two electronic books. The electronic books consist of modular lessons. Each modular lesson contains a presentation slide of a particular topic accompanied by a tutorial video. The first electronic book demonstrates how the analysis software called Matlab is used in engineering and technology. The usage is such that the extent of an engineer/technician knowledge is of Matlab directly relates to the success of that engineer/technician in academia and industry. The second electronic book is a course textbook on Solidworks, which is a CAD (Computer Aided Design) software package. Both electronic books consists of modular lessons with accompanying tutorial videos that can be used for specific courses in Matlab and Solidwork, or can be extracted as supplemental lectures in any other STEM courses. Another outcome was the creation of two new courses: CSC 267 Matlab Programming and CAD 140 Fundamentals of Solid Modeling. Both courses use the electronic books as the course's textbook or as supplemental material. At the conclusion of this grant, the electronic books and courses has impacted 454 students at HCC.

The second goal of this grant is to develop and pilot-test modular curricula using integrated multidisciplinary software to educate current and new students, in addition to incumbent workers. Video modular curricula were created and pilot-tested, and then were integrated into the two electronic books. The video modules were pilot tested in Calculus I and III, Differential Equations, Engineering Statics and Dynamics, the grant developed Computer Aided Design and Matlab courses.

The third goal of this grant is to assess the effectiveness of the modules, and to disseminate the demonstrated modular curricula and lesson-plan/tutorial manuals. Assessments were performed for effectiveness of the modular lessons during the pilot testing mentioned above. Assessments were based on student projects that used the Matlab and Solidworks software. These projects became part of the student’s portfolio that were used at job fairs and job interviews. The portfolios have proved to be an important part of getting jobs in engineering and technology. The student can easily prove that they understand the rapid prototyping and the design processes.

Masuk High School under the Perkins Dual Enrollment Program will be teaching HCC's CAD140 course. The CAD version of the electronic book produced by this grant will serve as the textbook.

Connecticut has a unique organization called the College of Technology. This organization was initiated by the NSF Regional Center for Next Generation Manufacturing, which consists of engineering/manufacturing representatives from each of the twelve community colleges, state universities and many of the state's private universities. This group meets monthly during the academic year to discuss curriculum, exchange information and to ensure seamless transfer between the community colleges and the universities. This organization identified the need for engineering/manufacturing students to know technical computing using Matlab software and Solidworks computer aided design software. The two electronic books will be an open, living resource to this group ensuring the book’s consistency and accuracy. This approach will ensure the sustainability and persistence of the outcomes of this grant.

During the grant period, an unexpected outcome was achieved. HCC's Engineering faculty and Art faculty were in discussions about art students learning CAD. Artists have been using CAD and 3d-printing to make sculptures. The CAD140 course will now be part of the Art core curriculum for the newly articulated transfer program between HCC and the Savannah College of Art and Design.

The electronic books are posted on the HCC website and are available to the general public.
